a	O
stage	O
which	O
permits	O
a	O
reasonable	O
assessment	O
of	O
the	O
existence	O
of	O
reserves.	O
The	O
deferral	O
policy	O
requires	O
management	O
to	O
make	O
certain	O
estimates	O
and	O
assumptions	O
about	O
future	O
events	O
or	O
circumstances	O
,	O
in	O
particular	O
whether	O
an	O
economically	O
viable	O
extraction	O
operation	O
can	O
be	O
established.	O
Estimates	O
and	O
assumptions	O
made	O
may	O
change	O
if	O
new	O
information	O
becomes	O
available.	O
During	O
the	O
year	O
the	O
Group	O
continued	O
defending	O
against	O
objections	O
to	O
expenditure	O
exemptions	O
and	O
applications	O
for	O
forfeiture	O
on	O
several	O
tenements.	O
Having	O
taken	O
legal	O
advice	O
,	O
the	O
Directors	O
of	O
Riversgold	O
are	O
of	O
the	O
opinion	O
that	O
their	O
applications	O
for	O
exemption	O
have	O
substantial	O
merit	O
and	O
the	O
risk	O
of	O
forfeiture	O
is	O
low.	O
Accounting	O
for	O
share-based	O
payments	O
Values	O
of	O
share-based	O
payments	O
have	O
been	O
estimated	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
fair	O
values	O
of	O
equity	O
instruments	O
granted.	O
Fair	O
values	O
of	O
share-based	O
payments	O
are	O
estimated	O
as	O
disclosed	O
in	O
note	O
1	O
(	O
o	O

)	O
.	O

Some	O
parameters	O
for	O
valuation	O
models	O
,	O
particularly	O
volatility	O
,	O
are	O
subject	O
to	O
significant	O
judgement.	O
The	O
sensitivity	O
of	O
valuations	O
to	O
changes	O
in	O
parameters	O
varies	O
considerably	O
,	O
but	O
option	O
valuations	O
can	O
be	O
particularly	O
sensitive	O
to	O
volatility.	O

note	O
18	O
for	O

30	O

2021	O
to	O
unearned	O
revenue	O
in	O
disposal	O
group	O
’	O

assets	O
and	O

as	O
the	O
sale	O
is	O
not	O

at	O
30	O
June	O
2021.	O
The	O
assets	O
of	O
the	O

group	O
,	O
which	O
consist	O
solely	O
of	O
capitalised	O

and	O

of	O
$2	O
,	O
011	O
,	O

,	O
and	O
are	O

of	O
$USD1	O
,	O
550	O
,	O
000	O
(	O
$AUD2	O
,	O
061	O
,	O

)	O

are	O
in	O

of	O
the	O
carrying	O
amount	O
of	O
the	O
assets.	O
The	O
$USD500	O
,	O
000	O
(	O
$AUD665	O
,	O
070	O
)	O
received	O
to	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O
is	O
recognised	O
as	O
a	O
liability	O
because	O
it	O
would	O
be	O
refundable	O
if	O
the	O
Group	O
withdraws	O
from	O

This	O
sale	O
is	O
not	O
treated	O
as	O
revenue	O
from	O
contracts	O
with	O
customers	O
because	O
the	O
assets	O
in	O
the	O
disposal	O
group	O
are	O
not	O

output	O
of	O

of	O
the	O
Group.	O

$USD500	O
,	O
000	O
(	O
$AUD	O
665	O
,	O
070	O
)	O
has	O
already	O
been	O
paid	O
by	O
the	O
purchaser	O
to	O
30	O
June	O
2021	O

the	O

agreement	O
if	O

Joint	O

may	O

The	O

s	O

entitle	O

holder	O
to	O

in	O
dividends	O
and	O
the	O
proceeds	O
on	O

to	O
the	O

of	O
and	O

on	O
the	O
shares	O
held.	O

of	O
hands	O

ordinary	O
shares	O
present	O

person	O
or	O

proxy	O

is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote	O
,	O
and	O
upon	O
a	O
poll	O
each	O
share	O
is	O
entitled	O
to	O
one	O
vote.	O

have	O
no	O

”	O

to	O

in	O

Responsibilities	O
of	O
the	O
directors	O
for	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
The	O
directors	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
and	O
the	O
Corporations	O
Act	O
2001	O
and	O
for	O
such	O
internal	O
control	O
as	O
the	O
directors	O
determine	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
that	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
and	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error.	O
In	O
preparing	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
directors	O
are	O
responsible	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O
concern	O
,	O
disclosing	O
,	O
as	O
applicable	O
,	O
matters	O
related	O
to	O
going	O
concern	O
and	O
using	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
unless	O
the	O
directors	O
either	O
intend	O
to	O
liquidate	O
the	O
Group	O
or	O
to	O
cease	O
operations	O
,	O
or	O
have	O
no	O
realistic	O
alternative	O
but	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O
Auditor	O
’	O
s	O
responsibilities	O
for	O
the	O
audit	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
Our	O
objectives	O
are	O
to	O
obtain	O
reasonable	O
assurance	O
about	O
whether	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
is	O
free	O
from	O
material	O
misstatement	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
and	O
to	O
issue	O
an	O
auditor	O
’	O
s	O
report	O
that	O
includes	O
our	O
opinion.	O
Reasonable	O
assurance	O
is	O
a	O
high	O
level	O
of	O
assurance	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
guarantee	O
that	O
an	O
audit	O
conducted	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
will	O
always	O
detect	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
when	O
it	O
exists.	O
Misstatements	O
can	O
arise	O
from	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
and	O
are	O
considered	O
material	O
if	O
,	O
individually	O
or	O
in	O
the	O
aggregate	O
,	O
they	O
could	O
reasonably	O
be	O
expected	O
to	O
influence	O
the	O
economic	O
decisions	O
of	O
users	O
taken	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
this	O
financial	O
report.	O
As	O
part	O
of	O
an	O
audit	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
the	O
Australian	O
Auditing	O
Standards	O
,	O
we	O
exercise	O
professional	O
judgement	O
and	O
maintain	O
professional	O
scepticism	O
throughout	O
the	O
audit.	O
We	O
also	O
:	O
-	O

Identify	O
and	O
assess	O
the	O
risks	O
of	O
material	O
misstatement	O
of	O
the	O
financial	O
report	O
,	O
whether	O
due	O
to	O
fraud	O
or	O
error	O
,	O
design	O
and	O
perform	O
audit	O
procedures	O
responsive	O
to	O
those	O
risks	O
,	O
and	O
obtain	O
audit	O
evidence	O
that	O
is	O
sufficient	O
and	O
appropriate	O
to	O
provide	O
a	O
basis	O
for	O
our	O
opinion.	O
The	O
risk	O
of	O
not	O
detecting	O
a	O
material	O
misstatement	O
resulting	O
from	O
fraud	O
is	O
higher	O
than	O
for	O
one	O
resulting	O
from	O
error	O
,	O
as	O
fraud	O
may	O
involve	O
collusion	O
,	O
forgery	O
,	O
intentional	O
omissions	O
,	O
misrepresentations	O
,	O
or	O
the	O
override	O
of	O
internal	O
control.	O
-	O

Obtain	O
an	O
understanding	O
of	O
internal	O
control	O
relevant	O
to	O
the	O
audit	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
design	O
audit	O
procedures	O
that	O
are	O
appropriate	O
in	O
the	O
circumstances	O
,	O
but	O
not	O
for	O
the	O
purpose	O
of	O
expressing	O
an	O
opinion	O
on	O
the	O
effectiveness	O
of	O
the	O
Group	O
’	O
s	O
internal	O
control.	O
-	O

Evaluate	O
the	O
appropriateness	O
of	O
accounting	O
policies	O
used	O
and	O
the	O
reasonableness	O
of	O
accounting	O
estimates	O

by	O

directors.	O
-	O

Conclude	O
on	O

of	O
the	O
directors	O
’	O
use	O
of	O
the	O
going	O
concern	O
basis	O
of	O
accounting	O
and	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
audit	O
evidence	O
obtained	O
,	O
whether	O
a	O
material	O

exists	O

to	O
events	O
or	O
conditions	O
that	O
may	O
cast	O
significant	O

on	O

’	O
s	O

to	O
continue	O
as	O
a	O
going	O

up	O

7	O
ASX	O

|	O
QUARTERLY	O

FOR	O
THE	O

ENDING	O
MARCH	O
31	O
2022	O
Further	O
Work	O
RC	O
Drilling	O
After	O
the	O
reporting	O
period	O
the	O
Company	O
commenced	O
a	O
3	O
,	O
000m	O
RC	O
drill	O
program	O
at	O
Yamarna	O
targeting	O
extensions	O
along	O
strike	O
and	O
at	O
depth	O
of	O
the	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
mineralisation	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
walk-up	O
targets	O
at	O
Eastern	O
Mafic.	O
As	O
at	O
the	O
date	O
of	O
this	O
announcement	O
approximately	O
1	O
,	O
900m	O
of	O
the	O
program	O
has	O
been	O
completed	O
with	O
slow	O
drilling	O
due	O
to	O
rig	O
breakdowns	O
and	O
ground	O
conditions.	O
The	O
first	O
three	O
batches	O
of	O
samples	O
are	O
at	O
the	O
laboratory	O
with	O
first	O
assays	O
expected	O
in	O
the	O
coming	O
month.	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
The	O
Company	O
has	O
engaged	O
well-credentialled	O
resource	O
consulting	O
group	O
Entech	O
to	O
define	O
an	O
initial	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
at	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
in	O
line	O
with	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
(	O
2012	O
)	O
.	O

According	O
to	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
an	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
is	O
defined	O
as	O
:	O
“	O
…	O

a	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
exploration	O
potential	O
of	O
a	O
mineral	O
deposit	O
in	O
a	O
defined	O
geological	O
setting	O
where	O
the	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
,	O
quoted	O
as	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
tonnes	O
and	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
grade	O
(	O
or	O
quality	O
)	O
,	O
relates	O
to	O
mineralisation	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
insufficient	O
exploration	O
to	O
estimate	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O
”	O
The	O
definition	O
of	O
this	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
,	O
planned	O
for	O
completion	O
in	O
the	O
June	O
quarter	O
,	O
will	O
be	O
fundamental	O
to	O
planning	O
further	O
drilling	O
required	O
to	O
upgrade	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
to	O
a	O
JORC	O
compliant	O
resource	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
testing	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
potential	O
beyond	O
the	O
current	O
drilling	O
limits.	O
WINCHESTER	O
(	O
CMO	O
75%	O
-	O

100%	O
)	O
The	O
Winchester	O
Project	O
is	O
located	O
to	O
the	O
north	O
of	O
the	O
Yamarna	O
Project	O
tenement	O
package	O
and	O
consists	O
of	O
two	O
tenements	O
covering	O
91km2	O
(	O
Figure	O
1	O
&	O
6	O
)	O
.	O

Winchester	O
contains	O
magmatic	O
hosted	O
polymetallic	O
(	O
Cu-	O
Ni-Co-PGE	O
)	O
mineralisation	O
interpreted	O
as	O
analogous	O
to	O
the	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
deposit.	O
Several	O
phases	O
of	O
exploration	O
have	O
been	O
completed	O
at	O
Winchester	O
,	O
however	O

,	O
base	O
metals	O

on	O

Yamarna	O
Belt	O

in	O
the	O

Goldfields	O
region	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O
The	O
Yamarna	O
Belt	O
is	O
considered	O
highly	O
prospective	O
for	O
copper-nickel-cobalt	O
(	O
Cu-Ni-Co	O
)	O
and	O
platinum	O
group	O
elements	O
(	O
PGE	O
)	O

Compliance	O
statement	O
1	O
This	O
statement	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
accounting	O
standards	O
and	O
policies	O
which	O
comply	O
with	O
Listing	O
Rule	O
19.11A.	O
2	O
This	O
statement	O
gives	O
a	O
true	O
and	O
fair	O
view	O
of	O
the	O
matters	O
disclosed.	O
Date	O
:	O
28th	O
April	O
2022	O
Authorised	O
by	O
:	O
By	O
the	O
Board	O
of	O
Cosmo	O
Metals	O
Ltd	O
(	O
Name	O
of	O
body	O
or	O
officer	O
authorising	O
release	O
–	O

see	O
note	O
4	O
)	O
Notes	O
1.	O
This	O
quarterly	O
cash	O
flow	O
report	O
and	O
the	O
accompanying	O
activity	O
report	O
provide	O
a	O
basis	O
for	O
informing	O
the	O
market	O
about	O
the	O
entity	O
’	O
s	O
activities	O
for	O
the	O
past	O
quarter	O
,	O
how	O
they	O
have	O
been	O
financed	O
and	O
the	O
effect	O
this	O
has	O
had	O
on	O
its	O
cash	O
position.	O
An	O
entity	O
that	O
wishes	O
to	O
disclose	O
additional	O
information	O
over	O
and	O
above	O
the	O
minimum	O
required	O
under	O
the	O
Listing	O
Rules	O
is	O
encouraged	O
to	O
do	O
so.	O
2.	O
If	O
this	O
quarterly	O
cash	O
flow	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
Australian	O
Accounting	O
Standards	O
,	O
the	O
definitions	O
in	O
,	O
and	O
provisions	O
of	O
,	O
AASB	O
6	O
:	O
Exploration	O
for	O
and	O
Evaluation	O
of	O
Mineral	O
Resources	O
and	O
AASB	O
107	O
:	O
Statement	O
of	O
Cash	O
Flows	O
apply	O
to	O
this	O
report.	O
If	O
this	O
quarterly	O
cash	O
flow	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
prepared	O
in	O
accordance	O
with	O
other	O
accounting	O
standards	O
agreed	O
by	O
ASX	O
pursuant	O
to	O
Listing	O
Rule	O
19.11A	O
,	O
the	O
corresponding	O
equivalent	O
standards	O
apply	O
to	O
this	O
report.	O
3.	O
Dividends	O
received	O
may	O
be	O
classified	O
either	O
as	O
cash	O
flows	O
from	O
operating	O
activities	O
or	O

from	O
investing	O
activities	O
,	O

on	O
the	O
accounting	O
policy	O
of	O
the	O
entity.	O
4.	O
If	O
this	O
report	O
has	O
been	O
authorised	O
for	O
release	O
to	O
the	O
market	O
by	O
your	O
board	O
of	O
directors	O
,	O
you	O
can	O
insert	O
here	O
:	O
“	O
By	O
the	O
board	O
”	O
.	O

it	O
has	O
been	O
authorised	O
for	O
release	O
to	O
the	O
market	O
by	O
a	O
committee	O
of	O
your	O
board	O
of	O
directors	O
,	O
you	O
can	O
insert	O
here	O
:	O
“	O
By	O
the	O
[name	O
of	O
board	O
committee	O
–	O

eg	O
Audit	O
and	O
Risk	O
Committee]	O
”	O
.	O

”	O
.	O

5.	O
If	O
this	O
report	O
has	O

’	O

average	O
184%.	O

confirms	O
that	O

’	O

are	O
bound	O
to	O
the	O

possibly	O

ion	O

iTECH	O
MINERALS	O
LTD	O
iTech	O
Minerals	O
Ltd	O
is	O
a	O
newly	O

battery	O
materials	O

minerals	O

its	O

Australian	O

company	O

for	O
kaolinite-halloysite	O

ion	O
adsorption	O
clay	O
rare	O
earth	O
element	O
mineralisation	O
and	O

the	O
Campoona	O

in	O
South	O
Australia.	O

was	O
used	O
for	O
the	O
preparation	O
of	O
the	O
three	O
replicates	O
for	O
each	O
sample	O
-	O

a	O
new	O
tile	O
was	O
used	O
for	O
each	O
additional	O
sample.	O
•	O

A	O
plastic	O
tube	O
was	O
placed	O
on	O
the	O
ceramic	O
tile	O
and	O
the	O
sample	O
placed	O
in	O
it	O
,	O
to	O
just	O
below	O
the	O
top	O
of	O
the	O
tube.	O
The	O
steel	O
pin	O
was	O
then	O
carefully	O
lowered	O
onto	O
the	O
sample	O
and	O
the	O
tube/sample/pin/ceramic	O
tile	O
carefully	O
moved	O
to	O
the	O
press.	O
•	O

The	O
arm	O
of	O
the	O
press	O
was	O
moved	O
to	O
achieve	O
a	O
weight	O
of	O
20	O
kg	O
on	O
the	O
digital	O
scale	O
,	O
for	O
approximately	O
5	O
seconds.	O
The	O
pressure	O
was	O
gradually	O
released	O
,	O
then	O
the	O
pin	O
carefully	O
removed.	O
This	O
resulted	O
in	O
a	O
disc	O
approximately	O
10	O
mm	O
thick.	O
•	O

The	O
disc	O
was	O
then	O
inverted	O
and	O
placed	O
,	O
along	O
with	O
8	O
others	O
,	O
in	O
a	O
800	O
Watt	O
microwave	O
and	O
dried	O
,	O
at	O
full	O
power	O
,	O
for	O
10	O
seconds.	O

'dried'	O
discs	O
were	O
then	O
placed	O
in	O
a	O

Slovakia	O
has	O
a	O
known	O
mining	O
history	O
dating	O
to	O
Celtic	O
times	O
and	O
earlier.	O

used	O
by	O

miners	O
at	O
Spania	O
Dolina	O
,	O
near	O
Banska	O
Bystrica	O
are	O
dated	O
as	O
early	O
as	O
2000-1700	O
BC.	O
Major	O
production	O
of	O
metals	O
(	O
primarily	O
copper	O
and	O
silver	O
)	O
occurred	O
during	O
the	O
medieval	O
period.	O
The	O
second	O
oldest	O
mining	O
institute	O
in	O
the	O
world	O
is	O
located	O
at	O
Banska	O
Stiavnica	O
and	O
the	O
local	O
population	O
is	O
proud	O
of	O
their	O
mining	O
heritage	O

ABOUT	O
MEEKA	O
GOLD	O
LIMITED	O
Meeka	O
Gold	O
(	O
ASX	O
:	O
MEK	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
junior	O
gold	O
explorer	O
with	O
a	O
portfolio	O
of	O
exploration	O
projects	O
across	O
Western	O
Australia.	O
Meeka	O
’	O
s	O
flagship	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
has	O
a	O
combined	O
343km	O
²	O

landholding	O
in	O
the	O
prolific	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Fields	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia	O
and	O
hosts	O
a	O
large	O
high	O
grade	O
1.1Moz	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O
The	O
Company	O
is	O
actively	O
exploring	O
on	O
this	O
tenure	O
while	O
also	O
progressing	O
toward	O
production	O
with	O
the	O
release	O
of	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
Scoping	O
Study	O
in	O
December	O
2021	O
outlining	O
a	O
robust	O
Project	O
that	O
produces	O
over	O
420koz	O
of	O
gold	O
and	O
delivers	O
significant	O
free	O
cashflow.	O
In	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
Murchison	O
Gold	O
Project	O
,	O
the	O
Company	O
owns	O
the	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
Gold	O
Project	O
in	O
southern	O
WA.	O
Circle	O
Valley	O
sits	O
in	O
the	O
Albany	O
Fraser	O
Mobile	O
Belt	O
which	O
hosts	O
the	O
Tropicana	O
gold	O
mine	O
(	O
3Moz	O
past	O
production	O
)	O
.	O

Gold	O
mineralisation	O
has	O
been	O
identified	O
in	O

FORWARD	O
LOOKING	O
STATEMENTS	O
Certain	O

to	O
the	O
Company	O
’	O
s	O
financial	O
position	O
,	O
strategy	O
and	O
expected	O
operating	O
results.	O
These	O
forward-looking	O
statements	O
involve	O
known	O
and	O
unknown	O
risks	O
,	O
uncertainties	O
,	O
assumptions	O
and	O
other	O
important	O
factors	O
that	O
could	O
cause	O
the	O
actual	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
of	O
the	O
Company	O
to	O
be	O
materially	O
different	O
from	O
future	O
results	O
,	O
performance	O
or	O
achievements	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
by	O
such	O
statements.	O
Actual	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
may	O
differ	O
materially	O
from	O
the	O
events	O
or	O
results	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O
forward-looking	O
statement	O
and	O
deviations	O
are	O
both	O
normal	O
and	O
to	O
be	O
expected.	O
Other	O
than	O
required	O
by	O
law	O
,	O
neither	O
the	O
Company	O
,	O
their	O
officers	O
nor	O
any	O
other	O
person	O
gives	O
any	O
representation	O

assurance	O
or	O
guarantee	O
that	O
the	O
occurrence	O
of	O
the	O
events	O
expressed	O
or	O
implied	O
in	O
any	O

statements	O
will	O
actually	O
occur.	O

COSMOMETALS.COM.AU	O
6	O
ASX	O
RELEASE	O
|	O
WIDE	O
COPPER	O
INTERSECTIONS	O
AT	O
MT	O
VENN	O
FURTHER	O
WORK	O
The	O
Company	O
is	O
engaging	O
a	O
well-credentialled	O
resource	O
consulting	O
group	O
to	O
define	O
an	O
initial	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
at	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
in	O
line	O
with	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
(	O
2012	O
)	O
.	O

According	O
to	O
the	O
JORC	O
Code	O
an	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
is	O
defined	O
as	O
:	O
“	O
…	O

a	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
of	O
the	O
exploration	O
potential	O
of	O
a	O
mineral	O
deposit	O
in	O
a	O
defined	O
geological	O
setting	O
where	O
the	O
statement	O
or	O
estimate	O
,	O
quoted	O
as	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
tonnes	O
and	O
a	O
range	O
of	O
grade	O
(	O
or	O
quality	O
)	O
,	O
relates	O
to	O
mineralisation	O
for	O
which	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
insufficient	O
exploration	O
to	O
estimate	O
a	O
Mineral	O
Resource.	O
”	O
The	O
definition	O
of	O
this	O
Exploration	O
Target	O
,	O
planned	O
for	O
completion	O
late	O
this	O
quarter	O
,	O
will	O
be	O
fundamental	O
to	O
planning	O
further	O
drilling	O
required	O
to	O
upgrade	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
to	O
a	O
JORC	O
compliant	O
resource	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
testing	O
the	O
mineralisation	O
potential	O
beyond	O
the	O
current	O
drilling	O
limits.	O
A	O
drilling	O
contractor	O
has	O
been	O
sourced	O
to	O
commence	O
this	O
program	O
in	O
March	O
to	O
avoid	O
potential	O
weather-	O
related	O
delays	O

fire	O

Cosmo	O
Metals	O
Ltd	O
(	O
Cosmo	O
;	O
ASX	O
:	O
CMO	O
)	O
is	O
an	O
ASX-listed	O
,	O
base	O
metals	O
exploration	O
company	O
focused	O
on	O
the	O
advancement	O
of	O
its	O
flagship	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
,	O
Winchester	O
and	O
Eastern	O
Mafic	O
projects	O
in	O
the	O
underexplored	O
Yamarna	O
Belt	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
Eastern	O
Goldfields	O
region	O
of	O
Western	O
Australia.	O
The	O
Yamarna	O
Belt	O
is	O
considered	O
highly	O
prospective	O
for	O
copper-nickel-cobalt	O
(	O
Cu-Ni-Co	O
)	O
and	O
platinum	O
group	O
elements	O
(	O
PGE	O
)	O
and	O
Cosmo	O
’	O
s	O
well	O
regarded	O
technical	O
team	O
is	O
advancing	O
exploration	O
on	O
multiple	O
fronts	O
to	O
unlock	O
the	O
potential	O
of	O
the	O
region.	O
With	O
previous	O
drilling	O
having	O
identified	O
sulphide	O
based	O
Cu-Ni-Co	O
mineralisation	O
at	O
Cosmo	O
’	O
s	O
key	O
projects	O
,	O
the	O
company	O
has	O
a	O
unique	O
opportunity	O
to	O
add	O
value	O
from	O
this	O
460km2	O
landholding	O
Competent	O
Persons	O

to	O

Forward-Looking	O

to	O

statements	O

Cosmo	O

other	O

are	O
not	O

,	O
"	O
"intend	O
,	O
"	O
"may	O
”	O
,	O
"potential	O
,	O
"	O
"should	O
,	O
"	O
and	O
similar	O
expressions	O

forward-looking	O
statements.	O

Cosmo	O

that	O

in	O

ASX	O

AT	O
MT	O
VENN	O
APPENDIX	O
B	O
JORC	O
CODE	O
,	O
2012	O
EDITION	O
–	O

TABLE	O
1	O
SECTION	O
1	O
-	O

SAMPLING	O
TECHNIQUES	O
AND	O
DATA	O
(	O
Criteria	O
in	O
this	O
section	O
apply	O
to	O
all	O
succeeding	O
sections	O
)	O
CRITERIA	O
COMMENTARY	O
Sampling	O
RC	O
samples	O
were	O
collected	O
into	O
calico	O
bags	O
over	O
1m	O
intervals	O
using	O
a	O
cyclone	O
splitter.	O
The	O
residual	O
bulk	O
techniques	O
samples	O
are	O
placed	O
in	O
piles	O
on	O
the	O
ground.	O
Two	O
cone	O
splits	O
are	O
taken	O
off	O
the	O
rig	O
splitter	O
for	O
RC	O
drilling.	O
Visually	O
prospective	O
zones	O
were	O
sampled	O
over	O
1m	O
intervals	O
and	O
sent	O
for	O
analysis	O
while	O
the	O
rest	O
of	O
the	O
hole	O
was	O
composited	O
over	O
4m	O
intervals	O
by	O
taking	O
a	O
spear	O
sample	O
from	O
each	O
1m	O
bag.	O
A	O
quality	O
assurance	O
/quality	O
control	O
(	O
QAQC	O
)	O
system	O
comprising	O
internal	O
and	O
laboratory	O
standards	O
,	O
blanks	O
and	O
duplicates	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
evaluate	O
analytical	O
results.	O
Drilling	O
Industry	O
standard	O
drilling	O
methods	O
and	O
equipment	O
were	O
utilised.	O
techniques	O
Reverse	O
Circulation	O
(	O
RC	O
)	O
Drilling	O
was	O
undertaken	O
by	O
Challenge	O
Drilling	O
using	O
130	O
to	O
140mm	O
diameter	O
drill	O
bits.	O
RC	O
drilling	O
employed	O
face	O
sampling	O
hammers	O
ensuring	O
contamination	O
during	O
sample	O
extraction	O
is	O
minimised.	O
Drill	O
sample	O
Sample	O
recovery	O
data	O
is	O
noted	O
qualitatively	O
in	O
geological	O
comments	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
logging	O
process.	O
Sample	O
recovery	O
condition	O
has	O
been	O
logged	O
for	O
every	O
geological	O
interval	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
logging	O
process.	O
No	O
quantitative	O
twinned	O
drilling	O
analysis	O
has	O
been	O
undertaken	O
and	O
no	O
information	O
is	O
available	O
to	O
assess	O
the	O
relationship	O
between	O
sample	O
recovery	O
and	O
grade.	O
Logging	O
Geological	O
logging	O
of	O
drilling	O
followed	O
established	O
company	O
procedures.	O
Qualitative	O
logging	O
of	O
samples	O
includes	O
lithology	O
,	O
mineralogy	O
,	O
alteration	O
,	O
veining	O
and	O
weathering.	O
Abundant	O
geological	O
comments	O
supplement	O
logged	O
intervals.	O
Sub-sampling	O
1m	O
cyclone	O
splits	O
and	O
4m	O
speared	O
composite	O
samples	O
were	O
taken	O
in	O
the	O
field.	O
Samples	O
were	O
prepared	O
and	O
techniques	O
and	O
analysed	O
at	O
ALS	O
Laboratories	O
Perth.	O
sample	O
All	O
samples	O
were	O
submitted	O
to	O
ALS	O
Laboratory	O
(	O
Perth	O
)	O
for	O
analyses.	O
Sample	O
preparation	O
included	O
:	O
preparation	O
Samples	O
were	O
weighed	O
,	O
crushed	O
(	O
such	O
that	O
a	O
minimum	O
of	O
70%	O
pass	O
2mm	O
)	O
and	O
pulverised	O
(	O
such	O
that	O
a	O
minimum	O
of	O
85%	O
pass	O

Yamarna	O
Project	O
hosts	O

the	O

Venn	O

complex.	O
This	O
complex	O
is	O

west	O
of	O
the	O
Yamarna	O
greenstone	O
belt.	O
The	O
mineralisation	O
encountered	O
in	O
the	O
Mt	O
Venn	O
drilling	O
suggests	O
that	O
sulphide	O
mineralisation	O
is	O
defined	O
by	O
a	O
prominent	O
long	O
EM	O
conductor	O
trend	O
and	O
shows	O
a	O
highly	O
sulfur-saturated	O
system	O
within	O
a	O
metamorphosed	O
dolerite	O
and	O
gabbro	O
sequence.	O
Visual	O
logging	O
of	O
sulphide	O
mineralogy	O
shows	O
pyrrhotite	O
dominant	O
with	O
chalcopyrite.	O
Drill	O
hole	O

list	O
of	O
drill	O
hole	O

,	O

and	O

Data	O
Results	O
were	O
reported	O
using	O
cut-off	O
levels	O
relevant	O
to	O
the	O
sample	O
type.	O

splits	O

significant	O

were	O
reported	O
for	O
grades	O

than	O
0.18%	O

a	O
maximum	O

of	O
2m.	O

grade	O
methods	O
intervals	O
are	O

using	O
a	O

cut-off	O

of	O
2m	O
internal	O
dilution.	O

maximum	O
or	O
minimum	O

been	O
applied.	O
